PITTSBURGH (AP) — Authorities say shots fired at a house party in Pittsburgh left two 17-year-olds dead and at least eight more people wounded.
North fatally shot Mubarak Soulemane in January 2020 as Soulemane sat in the driver’s seat of a car in West Haven, where a high-speed chase ended and police boxed in the car.
Officials say North posted $50,000 bail, was placed on paid administrative leave and his police powers were suspended.
The shooting happened at around 12:30 a.m. Sunday as hundreds of people had gathered at a short-term rental home.
Schubert said there was gunfire both inside and outside the rental home, "and potentially back and forth."
Others were hurt trying to flee, including two who broke bones while jumping out the building's windows.
Authorities say Trooper Brian North turned himself in to the state inspector general Tuesday evening.
A Connecticut state trooper has been charged with manslaughter in the 2020 fatal shooting of a man.
The inspector general's office released a report Wednesday saying the shooting was not justified.
This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.
North told officials he feared Soulemane was going to attack other officers with a knife.
Pittsburgh Police Chief Scott Schubert says the "vast majority" of them were underage.
Two male gunshot victims died and eight others were wounded by gunfire.
